reviewText: I was one of those who held on to his memory when the music studios were hustling "the British bands." Besides a longing for Roy Orbison's story, I wanted to hear again and again his unequaled voice. Here, after many years, his managing core of fans put together his story with his music in one inspirational package. From the same base as Buddy Holly (Texas) Roy honed his talent and ambition for all the world to enjoy. This gentle soul comes across from start to finish in this adoring visual biography of his life. His personal philosophy is worth noting here in light of the tragedies he overcame. There is a story late in this bio that details his late-70s concert appearance in the SF area, when he opened for audiences unfamiliar with his work. I heard about one night in Oakland when he opened to an impatient Eagles audience who booed him through a couple starting songs. Backstage, someone (possibly Don Henley)took the microphone away from Roy and gave the audience a dressing-down they never heard before: "If you don't shut up and listen to this great singer, we won't play here." Remarkably, the audience grew quiet and listened to about halfway through his next song and then their enthusiasm and rapt attention to his enthralling gifts took over into a couple encores and a worthy ovation. If you heard Orbison's operatic range and wonderfully crafted songs, you never forgot him. A lot of American groups and solo performers (Everly Brothers, Dion, Bobby Goldsboro (backup singer on Oh, Blue Angel)did not survive the British Invasion. Roy Orbison not only embraced it, but rose above it again and again. His biography seems to say that talent commands attention. Where Elvis got mired in repetition and self-mockery, Roy Orbison time and again looked for another way to demonstrate his gifts and for the most part succeeded. What a language, "Sha-la-laaah, doo-bi-wah" Yeah, yeah.

reviewText: Sony Legacy presents "IN DREAMS", featuring Roy Orbison nicknamed "The Big O", was an influential American singer songwriter and a pioneer of rock and roll whose recording career spanned more than four decades ... in the mid-1960s Orbison was internationally recognized for his ballads of lost love, rhythmically advanced melodies, characteristic dark sunglasses, and occasional distinctive usage of falsetto, typified in songs such as "Only The Lonely", "In Dreams", "Oh, Pretty Woman", "Crying" and "Running Scared" ... it was In 1987 Orbison was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and posthumously in 1989 into the National Academy of Popular Music/Songwriters Hall of Fame.Selections from "In Dreams" a classic performances by Roy Orbison and a clan of fellow musicians:1. Growing Up [3:09]2. Sun Records [3:48]3. Claudette [2:47]4. RCA to Monument [3:46]5. Creating Only the Lonely [4:18]6. Studio Sophistication [5:19]7. Crying [3:25]8. Dream Baby [3:12]9. Touring with the Beatles and the Rolling Stones [4:07]10. Songwriting [3:14]11. Oh, Pretty Woman [3:12]12. Success [2:49]13. Tragedy [4:33]14. Coping [4:15]15. Barbara and Rejuvenation [4:47]16. Collaborating with Emmylou Harris [3:32]17. Frustrations [5:04]18. Blue Velvet [6:03]19. Mystery Girl [3:23]20. Crying with K.D. Lang [4:08]21. Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Induction [1:21]22. Black and White Night [4:18]23. Lefty Wilbury [4:08]24. Credits [1:25]With Roy on this rockabilly occasion celebrating this legend's 70th Anniversary in a documentary with many of his admirers ... Chet Atkins, Bono, Johnny Cash, Cowboy Jack Clement, Fred Foster, Barry Gibb, Maurice Gibb, Robin Gibb, Emmylou Harris, George Harrison, Chris Isaak, Will Jennings, K.D. Lang , Jerry Lee Lewis, David Lynch, Jeff Lynne, Raul Malo, Willie Nelson, Tom Petty, Robert Plant, Bruce Springsteen, Bernie Taupin, Don Was and Dwight Yoakam.Must ask the following to take a bow Barbara Orbison (Executive Producer), Cass Paley (Re-Edit Producer) and Jed Hilly (Co-Producer) ... and the label that  made it all possible Sony Legacy --- this is a must have for all the fans plus a wonderful tribute to a man who brought joy to millions of people --- ROY ORBISON.Total Time: 90 mins on DVD ~ SNYL #86940 ~ (10/31/2006)

reviewText: This is 90 minute biography of the late-great- Roy Orbison was produced by his second wife, Barbara, and released by Sony’s Legacy label in 2006. It’s being re-released but with same UPC code and cover image in late 2013. That is why I’m just getting to this review – and you’ll see some other recent reviews here as well.There are already 21 reviews of the DVD on Amazon as I write this. I noted that some are really of a CD with the same title and a few reviewers – who have it lasted as this DVD – comment on it as a “concert”. It is not a concert – though there are a significant “complete songs” included from HBO’s “Black and White Night”, “Austin City Limits” and even early “American Bandstand” TV shows. But mostly it is a documentary on Orbison’s carrier from his first recording till he died in 2005. (There is virtually no time spent on his childhood – except that he says he dropped out of high school just before final exams. There is no narrator and interview clips (both new at the time of the doc’s production and archival pieces by Chet Atkins and Johnny Cash) are woven together with a pieces of a lengthy radio interview with Orbison.Though the majority – though not all – of his songs were written in a brief 10 year span (1955-65) and his career was spent reprising those hits – it’s interesting to learn who is friends were. Bono (from u2), Billy Wyman from the Stones and actor Martin Sheen.  The guy went through tragedy (his first wife died in a car crash and his first two sons perished in a house fire) but his music kept him in the public eye.The film is in standard screen aspect (not wide screen) and there are no “bonus features” on it.I followed Orbison’s career as a teenager in the 1950s and 60s and still learned new facts from this loving tribute to the guy with the unmistakable voice and dark sunglasses.I hope you found this review both informative and helpful.Steve Ramm“Anything Phonographic”
summary: 2006 documentary (not a concert)  produced by Orbison’s wife with many full performance and archival clips. Not wide screen  No
